awd_abstract_narration:
Much of modern probability research seeks to understand the behavior of large and complex random systems (for instance, growth in disordered media, cracking, turbulent fluids, or traffic flow) with an aim towards developing theories with predictive and statistical value. While one can try to directly model such systems on computers, their size and complexity often render such attempts fruitless. Instead, one can look for models of such systems that are complex enough to display all of the phenomena under study, yet simple enough to admit exact mathematical computation to probe that behavior. Integrable probability is the theory behind discovering and subsequently analyzing such models. This project seeks to unify the area and various recent breakthroughs and in so doing discover a host of new types of integrable probability systems, new tools for their analysis, and new large-scale universal phenomena.

Integrable probability is an area of research at the interface between probability, mathematical physics, and statistical physics on the one hand, and representation theory and integrable systems on the other. Integrable probabilistic systems are characterized by two properties: It is possible to write down concise and exact formulas for expectations of a variety of interesting observables of the systems; and asymptotics of the systems, observables, and formulas provide access to exact descriptions of new phenomena and universality classes (containing more than just integrable examples). The discovery and analysis of integrable probabilistic systems hinges upon underlying algebraic structure. These integrable probabilistic systems can be viewed as projections of powerful objects whose origins lie in representation theory and integrable systems. There is a rich history of major breakthroughs in the study of integrable probabilistic systems, including the six-vertex model, Ising model, and more recently certain models in the KPZ universality class. The basic mechanisms at the heart of many of these existing results are Schur / Macdonald processes (built off the structure of symmetric polynomials) and quantum integrable systems (built off solutions to the Yang-Baxter equation and the Bethe ansatz). Each mechanism has produced breakthrough results, such as the recent resolution of the 25-year-old physics conjecture that the KPZ stochastic partial differential equation is in the KPZ universality class. Until recently, these two routes to integrable probability have existed relatively separately. The goal of the proposed project is to create a unified theory of integrable probability, combining and generalizing the methods of Schur / Macdonald processes and quantum integrable systems and, complementarily, extracting new analyzable models and uncovering new probabilistic or physical phenomena.

This report focuses on the intellectual merit and broader impact of PI Corwin’s portion of this FRG.

Intellectual Merit: Probabilistic systems evolve according to specific rules which are driven by some form of randomness (e.g. a random walker jumps left or right with probability ½). Most probabilistic systems are either too simple to be useful in modeling the real world, or too complex to be analyzable. Integrable probability systems strike a balance – they are both useful and analyzable. In particular, they are characterized by two properties: It is possible to write down concise and exact formulas for expectations of a variety of interesting observables of the systems; and asymptotics of these systems, observables and formulas provide access to exact description of new phenomena and universality class. These universality classes generally include many more systems than just the integrable models and hence they have important broader impacts (detailed below).

This FRG supported research on the algebraic origins and probabilistic applications of integrable probabilistic systems. Central to their origins is the theory of symmetric functions and quantum integrable systems. In particular, FRG funded research has demonstrate the key role played by solutions to the Yang-Baxter equation in the development and analysis of these special systems. This equation was first studied in the context of the Ising model, though has taken a central role in the development of quantum group theory and the algebraic Bethe ansatz. FRG work has led to the development of new classes of symmetric functions with remarkable combinatorial properties that generalize classical families like the Schur polynomials. Along with these algebraic developments, the FRG has also shown how these tools can be used to study asymptotic and statistical behavior of integrable interacting particle systems, growth models and polymer models subject to boundary conditions and inhomogeneities; and have used these tools to study fractal properties of the evolution of these systems. The FRG has also led to important advances in the study of multispecies systems (e.g. where there are different types of particles which relate to each other with various types of rules) and Gibbsian line ensembles (e.g. where there are many paths which interact with each other according to certain energetic costs). The FRG has been a striking success at sparking and supporting new research with are over 224 papers during the FRG period written by group members, and 87 of these acknowledge direct support of the grants.

Broader Impact: Imagine a crystal nucleating, a cancer spreading, a coffee stain expanding, a turbulent fluid mixing, a crack developing, or Ribosomes moving along RNA. Each of these systems (and many othes) have been studied by mathematical models arising in Integrable Probability. Using the tools developed in here, we have been able to make extremely precise predictions about the long-time behavior of these systems, as well as about their fractal and statistical properties. We have also been able to determine the effect of the geometry in which these systems evolve and boundary conditions to which they are subject.

This FRG has had extensive educational, professional, and human resource impact. The FRG ran two workshops (at Columbia and MIT) and one summer school (at University of Virginia). PI Corwin organized:

  • Two summer schools (joint with PI Borodin) and funded some participants through the FRG
  • A jumbo semester program at the NSF-funded Mathematical Science Research Institute on a theme including Integrable Probability
  • A weekly Integrable Probability seminar (that moved online after COVID), other weekly and periodic seminars including the One World Probability Seminar, as well as special sessions on Integrable Probability at the World Congress in Probability and the Open Online Probability School
  • Two special semesters at Columbia including four topics courses and semester visits by Herbert Spohn, Makiko Sasada and Julien Randon-Furling.

During this grant, PI Corwin has trained/mentored:

  • 3 high school students through weekly internships
  • 12 undergraduates (3 female) through senior theses and reading groups
  • 9 Ph.D. candidates (3 female)
  • 8 postdocs (1 female)
  • 3 tenure track faculty
  • He has also created the Math Modeling Workshop which involved over 200 undergraduates during the semester and 18 during an intensive summer REU.

PI Corwin serves on scientific leadership boards including the Columbia Data Science Institute, Columbia Probability and Society Initiative (which he directs), One World Probability Seminar, ICERM (Institute for Computations and Experimental Research in Mathematics), MSRI (Mathematical Science Research Institute). He chairs the Columbia math department Diversity, Equity and Inclusion committee and is a member of a STEM-wide DEI super-committee; he previously chaired the AMS Centennial Fellowship selection committee. The PI and other FRG members have also been working on a book on Integrable Probability and have published various other survey and review articles in this direction during the grants duration.
